Line 1: Line 1:
{{Politics of Egypt}}
{{Politics of Egypt}}
â
Early '''parliamentary elections''' will be held in [[Egypt]] in October 2011,<ref>http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1629149.php/Egypt-to-hold-parliamentary-elections-in-September</ref> following the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|ouster]] of President [[Hosni Mubarak]], after which the interim military rulers dissolved the [[parliament of Egypt]]. Originally, the election was assumed to be held in September 2011, but this was postponed.{{Why?|date=July 2011}}<ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7439632.html</ref>
+
Early '''parliamentary elections''' will be held in [[Egypt]] in October 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1629149.php/Egypt-to-hold-parliamentary-elections-in-September |title=Egypt to hold parliamentary elections in September |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2011-03-28 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref> following the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|ouster]] of President [[Hosni Mubarak]], after which the interim military rulers dissolved the [[parliament of Egypt]]. Originally, the election was assumed to be held in September 2011, but this was postponed.{{Why?|date=July 2011}}<ref>{{cite web|author=F_483 |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7439632.html |title=Egyptian Parliamentary elections postponed to October or November: MENA - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
==Background==
==Background==
â
In [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|late 2010]] a parliamentary election was held, though it was followed by controversy and repression as well as accusations of fraud.<ref>http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/top/all/7425408.html</ref>
+
In [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|late 2010]] a parliamentary election was held, though it was followed by controversy and repression as well as accusations of fraud.<ref>[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/top/all/7425408.html ]{{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref>
Following similar events in [[2010â2011 Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]], Egyptian activists called for protesters to turn up in cities around Egypt on various specially-designated days of rages. Though violence was reported at some points, protests were largely peaceful with the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|army]] staying quiet until 10 February with calls for Mubrak to resign. The following day, Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] announced Mubarak's resignation from the presidency while turning power over to the military. Head of the military [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] would lead the country in the interim period till the election. The announcement was followed by widspread celebrations in Egypt and international reactions.
Following similar events in [[2010â2011 Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]], Egyptian activists called for protesters to turn up in cities around Egypt on various specially-designated days of rages. Though violence was reported at some points, protests were largely peaceful with the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|army]] staying quiet until 10 February with calls for Mubrak to resign. The following day, Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] announced Mubarak's resignation from the presidency while turning power over to the military. Head of the military [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] would lead the country in the interim period till the election. The announcement was followed by widspread celebrations in Egypt and international reactions.
Line 11: Line 11:
===New electoral law===
===New electoral law===
â
There were previously concerns that a change to the electoral system would be required, as the current district-based [[first-past-the-post]] system would favour the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]].<ref>http://www.carnegieendowment.org/publications/index.cfm?fa=view&id=42817</ref> The National Democratic Party was however dissolved in April.
+
There were previously concerns that a change to the electoral system would be required, as the current district-based [[first-past-the-post]] system would favour the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carnegieendowment.org/publications/index.cfm?fa=view&id=42817 |title=Egyptâs Draft Constitutional Amendments Answer Some Questions and Raise Others - Carnegie Endowment for International Peace |publisher=Carnegieendowment.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref> The National Democratic Party was however dissolved in April.
â
The draft law for the electoral system to be used was revealed on 30 May 2011; controversially, it retained [[First-past-the-post voting|FPTP]] for two thirds of the seats, with only one third of the seats elected by [[proportional representation]].<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13291/Egypt/Politics-/Draft-law-draw-introducing-mixed-electoral-system-.aspx</ref>
+
The draft law for the electoral system to be used was revealed on 30 May 2011; controversially, it retained [[First-past-the-post voting|FPTP]] for two thirds of the seats, with only one third of the seats elected by [[proportional representation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13291/Egypt/Politics-/Draft-law-draw-introducing-mixed-electoral-system-.aspx |title=Draft law introducing mixed electoral system triggers intense debate - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-30 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
â
On 7 July 2011, the caretaker government approved the new electoral law. It foresees a 50â50 division between proportional seats and FPTP seats; the minimum age limit for candidates is also to be reduced from 30 to 25.<ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7432343.html</ref>
+
On 7 July 2011, the caretaker government approved the new electoral law. It foresees a 50â50 division between proportional seats and FPTP seats; the minimum age limit for candidates is also to be reduced from 30 to 25.<ref>{{cite web|author=F_474 |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7432343.html |title=Egypt's caretaker government passes draft law on parliamentary vote - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=2011-07-07 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
â
On 21 July 2011, the SCAF announced:<reF>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7447621.html</ref>
+
On 21 July 2011, the SCAF announced:<ref>{{cite web|author=F_161 |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7447621.html |title=Egypt to hold parliamentary elections in three rounds - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=2011-07-21 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
* that the election (for both the People's Assembly and the Shura Council) would be held in three rounds in October, with 15-day intervals in-between;
* that the election (for both the People's Assembly and the Shura Council) would be held in three rounds in October, with 15-day intervals in-between;
* that half the seats would be reserved for workers and farmers;
* that half the seats would be reserved for workers and farmers;
Line 23: Line 23:
==Parties==
==Parties==
â
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced on 15 February it would form the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] to run in the election.<ref>http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028941,00.html</ref> The [[Al-Wasat Party]], a moderate Islamic faction of the Muslim Brotherhood, was officially approved as a party on 19 February, fifteen years after its foundation.
+
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced on 15 February it would form the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] to run in the election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028941,00.html |title=Egypt: Muslim Brotherhood plans political party - Israel News, Ynetnews |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date=1995-06-20 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref> The [[Al-Wasat Party]], a moderate Islamic faction of the Muslim Brotherhood, was officially approved as a party on 19 February, fifteen years after its foundation.
â
The Freedom and Justice Party and the liberal [[New Wafd Party]] announced on 13 June 2011 that they would contest the election in an alliance.<ref>http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypts-muslim-brotherhood-forms-coalition-with-liberal-party/2011/06/13/AGQI7OTH_story.html</ref>
+
The Freedom and Justice Party and the liberal [[New Wafd Party]] announced on 13 June 2011 that they would contest the election in an alliance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypts-muslim-brotherhood-forms-coalition-with-liberal-party/2011/06/13/AGQI7OTH_story.html |title=Egyptâs Muslim Brotherhood forms coalition |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2011-02-22 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
As a reaction to this centre-right alliance, the different liberal democratic and centrist parties intensified cooperation. Five parties have drafted a joint statement criticising the current electoral law and proposing a new one.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/14212/Egypt/Politics-/Democratic-Egyptian-political-parties-to-issue-a-j.aspx |title=Democratic Egyptian political parties to issue a joint statement on new electoral law |newspaper= [[Al-Ahram]] Online |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011}}</ref> On 16 August, 15 political and social movements announced an electoral alliance, the [[The Egyptian Bloc|Egyptian Bloc]]. It consists of liberal, secularist, and centre-left political parties, as well as social organisations and labour unions, and also the traditional Islamic Sufi Liberation Party. Its main objective is to prevent an imminent electoral victory of the Muslim Brotherhood, respectively Freedom and Justice Party. The Wafd Party announced to abandon its alliance with the Islamists over discrepancies concerning the prospective constitution, and to join the new liberal coalition instead.<ref name="Arabiya">{{Citation |first=Yasmine |last=Saleh |title=Egypt liberals launch âThe Egyptian Blocâ to counter Islamists in Nov. vote |newspaper=Al Arabiya News |date=16 Aug 2011 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/16/162562.html |accessdate=4 Sep 2011}}</ref>
As a reaction to this centre-right alliance, the different liberal democratic and centrist parties intensified cooperation. Five parties have drafted a joint statement criticising the current electoral law and proposing a new one.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/14212/Egypt/Politics-/Democratic-Egyptian-political-parties-to-issue-a-j.aspx |title=Democratic Egyptian political parties to issue a joint statement on new electoral law |newspaper= [[Al-Ahram]] Online |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011}}</ref> On 16 August, 15 political and social movements announced an electoral alliance, the [[The Egyptian Bloc|Egyptian Bloc]]. It consists of liberal, secularist, and centre-left political parties, as well as social organisations and labour unions, and also the traditional Islamic Sufi Liberation Party. Its main objective is to prevent an imminent electoral victory of the Muslim Brotherhood, respectively Freedom and Justice Party. The Wafd Party announced to abandon its alliance with the Islamists over discrepancies concerning the prospective constitution, and to join the new liberal coalition instead.<ref name="Arabiya">{{Citation |first=Yasmine |last=Saleh |title=Egypt liberals launch âThe Egyptian Blocâ to counter Islamists in Nov. vote |newspaper=Al Arabiya News |date=16 Aug 2011 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/16/162562.html |accessdate=4 Sep 2011}}</ref>
Line 32: Line 32:
==Monitors==
==Monitors==
â
The [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|announced]] that it would bar foreign monitors because of what it claimed was the preservation of Egyptian sovereingty.<Ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011720222415556480.html</ref>
+
The [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|announced]] that it would bar foreign monitors because of what it claimed was the preservation of Egyptian sovereingty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011720222415556480.html |title=Egypt not to allow foreign poll monitors - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-07-21 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
==Polls==
==Polls==
â
A 9-20 March poll survey amongst 615 voting age Egyptians by the International Peace Institute showed that [[New Wafd Party]], the oldest liberal party, had the support of 23 percent, 12 percent of Egyptian voters would vote for the [[Freedom and Justice Party]], and 10 percent still supported the now dissolved [[National Democratic Party]].<ref>http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=294799&IssueID=2117</ref><ref>http://www.ipinst.org/images/pdfs/egypt-poll-results-april2011.pdf</ref>
+
A 9-20 March poll survey amongst 615 voting age Egyptians by the International Peace Institute showed that [[New Wafd Party]], the oldest liberal party, had the support of 23 percent, 12 percent of Egyptian voters would vote for the [[Freedom and Justice Party]], and 10 percent still supported the now dissolved [[National Democratic Party]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Ø¹Ø§Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙØ¯Ø±Ø¬ÙÙ ÙÙØ§ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØ²ÙØ±Ù |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=294799&IssueID=2117 |title=Ø§Ø³ØªØ·ÙØ§Ø¹ Ø±Ø£Ù Ø£ÙØ±ÙÙÙ: Ù¢Ù£% ÙØ¤ÙØ¯ÙÙ Â«Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯Â» ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ§ÙØªØ®Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§ÙÙØ© ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ù Ù¡Ù¢% ÙÙÂ«Ø§ÙØ¥Ø®ÙØ§ÙÂ» ÙÙ¡Ù % ÙÙÂ«Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙÂ» |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite paper|author=Charney Research |url=http://www.ipinst.org/images/pdfs/egypt-poll-results-april2011.pdf |title=EGYPT NATIONAL SURVEY |publisher=International Peace Institute Poll |date=2011-03-20 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
â
A Gallup poll from June 2011 showed that the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] had the support of 15 percent of the survey group, with over 60 % of the people undecided.<ref>http://patdollard.com/2011/06/gallup-15-of-egyptians-support-muslim-brotherhood-69-want-religious-leaders-to-have-advisory-role/</ref> The dissolved would have scored [[National Democratic Party]] 10 percent, the liberal [[New Wafd Party]] 9 percent, and the newly launched [[Wasat Party]] 5 percent.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
+
A Gallup poll from June 2011 showed that the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] had the support of 15 percent of the survey group, with over 60 % of the people undecided.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://patdollard.com/2011/06/gallup-15-of-egyptians-support-muslim-brotherhood-69-want-religious-leaders-to-have-advisory-role/ |title=Gallup: 15% Of Egyptians Support Muslim Brotherhood, 69% Want Religious Leaders To Have âAdvisory Roleâ at Pat Dollard |publisher=Patdollard.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref> The dissolved would have scored [[National Democratic Party]] 10 percent, the liberal [[New Wafd Party]] 9 percent, and the newly launched [[Wasat Party]] 5 percent.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
â
July 7 public opinion survey by Al Jazeera showed following voting intentions: 46% of those polled indicated they would vote for the Muslim Brotherhood, running under the Freedom and Justice Party banner, in the November parliamentary elections. An additional 27% would support the Salafist-backed Nour Party. The Wasat party, which represents a moderate islamism, came in third with 6%. The youth-based Hizb ElAdl, or Justice Party, was the top ranking secularist group, with only 5%.<ref>http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/1/shut-up-egypt-is-muslim/</ref>
+
July 7 public opinion survey by Al Jazeera showed following voting intentions: 46% of those polled indicated they would vote for the Muslim Brotherhood, running under the Freedom and Justice Party banner, in the November parliamentary elections. An additional 27% would support the Salafist-backed Nour Party. The Wasat party, which represents a moderate islamism, came in third with 6%. The youth-based Hizb ElAdl, or Justice Party, was the top ranking secularist group, with only 5%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/1/shut-up-egypt-is-muslim/ |title=EDITORIAL: Shut up, Egypt is Muslim |publisher=Washington Times |date=2011-08-01 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
â
July 26 survey by Newsweek/Daily Beast showed following results: 29% Not sure/Uned, 17% Frdecideedom and Justice Party, 11% Al-Wafd Party, 7% National Democratic Party, 7% [[Free Egyptians Party]], 5% Justice Party, 4% [[Freedom Egypt Party]], 3% [[Egyptian Current Party]], 3% [[Dignity Party (Egypt)|Dignity Party]], 2% [[Socialist Labour Party (Egypt)|Egyptian Labor Party]], 2% [[El-Ghad Party]], 2% [[National Progressive Unionist Party|Tagammu Party]], 1% AlWasat Party, 1% [[Democratic Front Party]], 7% Other. <ref>http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/07/26/egypt-political-poll-muslim-brotherhood-influence-troubles-for-west.html</ref>
+
July 26 survey by Newsweek/Daily Beast showed following results: 29% Not sure/Uned, 17% Frdecideedom and Justice Party, 11% Al-Wafd Party, 7% National Democratic Party, 7% [[Free Egyptians Party]], 5% Justice Party, 4% [[Freedom Egypt Party]], 3% [[Egyptian Current Party]], 3% [[Dignity Party (Egypt)|Dignity Party]], 2% [[Socialist Labour Party (Egypt)|Egyptian Labor Party]], 2% [[El-Ghad Party]], 2% [[National Progressive Unionist Party|Tagammu Party]], 1% AlWasat Party, 1% [[Democratic Front Party]], 7% Other. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/07/26/egypt-political-poll-muslim-brotherhood-influence-troubles-for-west.html |title=Egypt Political Poll: Muslim Brotherhood Influence, Troubles For West |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=2011-07-26 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
â
An August 2011 survey by Danish Institute for Parties and Democracy showed the following results: Egypt can expect a large turnout of voters in the upcoming parliamentary elections â more than 80% say that they are likely to vote, only 17.7% would not go to the polls. More than half of the voters (57.1%) are still undecided. The Muslim Brotherhoodâs âFreedom and Justice Partyâ has support from 31.5% of the decided voters. However, the âFreedom and Justice Partyâ splits the electorate in half â 39% of the voters view the party unfavourably vs. 36% in the favourable group. The political parties in general suffer from a lack of trust from the electorate â only the âRevolutionary Youth Coalitionâ has a strong favourable/unfavourable (44% vs. 24%) standing. The party has a double digit support of 17.2%. The Wafd Party received 14.8%, Free Egyptians 7.5%, Nour 6.0%, [[Egyptian Social Democratic Party]] 5.2%, [[Arab Democratic Nasserist Party|Nasserites]] 3.7%, Justice Party 2.6%, Tagammu 2.2%. Eleven other parties were also taken into account by the surveyors.<ref>http://dipd.dk/2011/08/egypt-survey-favourable-to-amr-moussa/</ref><ref>http://dipd.dk/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Egypt-Survey-1-August-2011.pdf</ref>
+
An August 2011 survey by Danish Institute for Parties and Democracy showed the following results: Egypt can expect a large turnout of voters in the upcoming parliamentary elections â more than 80% say that they are likely to vote, only 17.7% would not go to the polls. More than half of the voters (57.1%) are still undecided. The Muslim Brotherhoodâs âFreedom and Justice Partyâ has support from 31.5% of the decided voters. However, the âFreedom and Justice Partyâ splits the electorate in half â 39% of the voters view the party unfavourably vs. 36% in the favourable group. The political parties in general suffer from a lack of trust from the electorate â only the âRevolutionary Youth Coalitionâ has a strong favourable/unfavourable (44% vs. 24%) standing. The party has a double digit support of 17.2%. The Wafd Party received 14.8%, Free Egyptians 7.5%, Nour 6.0%, [[Egyptian Social Democratic Party]] 5.2%, [[Arab Democratic Nasserist Party|Nasserites]] 3.7%, Justice Party 2.6%, Tagammu 2.2%. Eleven other parties were also taken into account by the surveyors.<ref>{{cite web|author=23.08.2011 by DIPDPhoto: UN Alliance of Civilizations |url=http://dipd.dk/2011/08/egypt-survey-favourable-to-amr-moussa/ |title=Survey favourable to Amr Moussa | DIPD |publisher=Dipd.dk |date=2011-08-23 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite paper|url=http://dipd.dk/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Egypt-Survey-1-August-2011.pdf |title=National Voter Survey in Egypt |publisher=Al-Ahram Centre for Political and Strategic Studies (ACPSS) |date=2011-08-22 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref>
